column4: if I'm using ubuntu, do I have access to (almost) all the packages in debian sid?
no, that'S a different (and not compatible) distro
I'm a little confused, the about page says: "Most of the packages in Ubuntu universe are also in Debian"
so there seems to be a relation
halitech: what I mean is if there's package x in debian sid, will I be able to get package x in ubuntu?
ubuntu users debian as the upstream /source/.
so ubuntu "universe" packages are close to a superset of debians "unstable", at least at the time of ubuntu's release?
frevidar:Dur to the different release process the packages are usually build with a different toolchain, so debian and ubuntu are not binary compatible in the strict sense
I'm not really worried about binary compatibility. I just don't want to use ubuntu if it provides significantly less packages than debian
all the good stuff is there, and a fair amount of ubuntu maintainers is also debian maintainers. If you don't need really exotic or bleeding edge stuff you should be fine with ubuntu
occasionally I'll need stuff thats exotic
you can still build it from source
what I found annoying about debian, whilst I was generally happy with stable, backporting things seemed to be a pain when I did want something new
that was a few years ago though
i think you'll be happy with ubuntu... if not give sidux a try
